message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing symptoms of lactose intolerance, which can be diagnosed using a hydrogen breath test. A positive result indicates that the patient is unable to absorb lactose properly and it is being fermented by bacteria in the colon, producing hydrogen that is exhaled and measured in the breath test. The other options are not specific to diagnosing lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing lactose intolerance, which can be diagnosed with a hydrogen breath test. After ingesting lactose, bacteria in the colon break it down, producing hydrogen gas. This gas is then absorbed into the bloodstream and exhaled through the lungs, where it can be detected with a breath test. A negative result would indicate that the patient is not lactose intolerant, while a positive result would indicate that they are. Technetium 99 scan and abdominal ultrasound would not be appropriate tests for diagnosing lactose intolerance.

After consuming lactose, the patient will exhale more hydrogen than usual if they are lactose intolerant. The other options are not relevant for diagnosing lactose intolerance.

A positive result indicates that hydrogen is produced by bacterial fermentation of undigested lactose in the colon. The other options are not appropriate for diagnosing lactose intolerance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lactose intolerance, which can be diagnosed by a hydrogen breath test. In this test, the patient drinks a lactose solution and exhales into a machine that measures hydrogen levels. A positive result indicates that the lactose was not properly digested and fermented by bacteria, leading to increased hydrogen production. A negative result would indicate that the patient is able to digest lactose normally. A technetium 99 scan and abdominal ultrasound would not be useful in diagnosing lactose intolerance.
